citation.article-title: Proposal of Histophilus somni gen. nov., sp. nov. for the three species incertae sedis 'Haemophilus somnus', 'Haemophilus agni' and 'Histophilus ovis'.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Histophilus (His.to′phi.lus. Gr. n. histos tissue; N.L. adj. philus from Gr. adj. philos friendly; N.L. masc. n. Histophilus the tissue friend).
Histophilus is a novel genus within the family Pasteurellaceae Pohl (1979) 1981.
The genus consists of Gram-negative, non-motile rods or coccobacilli.
Growth is mesophilic and capnophilic and is not dependent on V-factor or X-factor.
Glucose is fermented without gas production.
Alkaline phosphatase test is positive and nitrate is reduced.
Simmons' citrate, Voges–Proskauer, arginine dihydrolase and ornithine decarboxylase tests are negative and there is no fermentation of adonitol or l-sorbose.
Phenotypic characters that separate the genus Histophilus from other genera of the family Pasteurellaceae are given in Table 2.
The genus is not closely phylogenetically related to any other taxon within the Pasteurellaceae.
The type species of the genus is Histophilus somni.
